Mechanistic interpretations and insights for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane with CO2 over alkali metal modified Zn/SSZ-13 catalyst Lizhi Wu Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Wenchun Zheng Investigation Formal analysis Xiaofang Wang Investigation Formal analysis Juncheng He Investigation Formal analysis Caixin Zou Investigation Formal analysis Mengjia Zhu Investigation Formal analysis Bo Liu Investigation Formal analysis Li Tan Investigation Formal analysis Yu Tang Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Institute of Molecular Catalysis and In-situ/operando Studies, Institute of Molecular Engineering Plus, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, 350108, PR China Institute of Molecular Catalysis and In-situ/operando Studies Institute of Molecular Engineering Plus College of Chemistry Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350108 PR China Institute of Molecular Catalysis and In-situ/operando Studies, Institute of Molecular Engineering Plus, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, 350108, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Alkali metal promoted Zn/SSZ-13 catalysts were investigated for ethane dehydrogenation (EDH) and CO2-assisted oxidative ethane dehydrogenation (CO2-EDH). The Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 demonstrated enhanced ethane dehydrogenation performance, achieving 0.381 mol C2H4 gZn -1 h-1 with a low deactivation rate constant of (kd) of 0.04 h-1 in the CO2-EDH process after 440 min time on stream, compared to the unmodified Zn/SSZ-13 catalyst. Comprehensive characterizations revealed that the isolated Zn2+ species serve as the active sites for dehydrogenation, while the addition of alkali metals compensate the acid sites of SSZ-13, effectively suppressing the side reactions such as cracking. Moreover, the introduction of CO2 mitigates Zn loss and enhances catalyst activity and stability by coupling with the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS), which also suppress the coke deposition. Investigation of vary CO2 content indicated that higher CO2 concentrations significantly suppress Zn loss and increase the proportion of the RWGS reaction, thereby improving CO2-EDH catalytic performance. This work elucidates the active phase of ethane dehydrogenation and highlights the role of alkali metals and CO2 in the CO2-EDH process over Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, providing valuable insights for designing high-performance CO2-EDH catalysts. Introduction Ethylene, as one of the most important basic chemical raw materials, has been widely applied into the synthesis of polyethylene, vinyl chloride, styrene, ethylene oxide [1–7]. In recent years, the steadily increasing demand for ethylene derivatives has driven a sharp rise in ethylene production. Traditional methods for ethylene production primarily rely on the petroleum route, involving the steam cracking of naphtha and gasoil. However, these processes are associated with several disadvantages, including low ethylene yield, high reaction temperatures, and significant energy consumption. Recently, advancements in shale gas, combustible ice, and natural gas exploration technologies have made ethane an abundant and cost-effective raw material for ethylene production [8–13]. Correspondingly, ethane dehydrogenation to ethylene has become one of the most promising routes and is attracting more and more attention, owing to the advantages of low energy consumption, high ethylene yield, environmentally friendly as well as the mere H2 byproduct. Although the steam cracking of ethane to ethylene has been commercialized, it remains constrained by high reaction temperatures, low equilibrium conversions, and short catalyst lifecycles. In comparison, ethane oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) offers several advantages over non-oxidative dehydrogenation technology (EDH): (1) it could break the equilibrium conversion and further promote the ethane conversion, (2) the exothermic reaction could make the reaction condition milder when use strong oxidizing agent such as O2 and N2O, (3) the introduction of oxidant would reduce the generation of coke. Hence, it is of great significance to investigate the ODH route for upgrading ethylene production. Correspondingly, different oxidants including O2, N2O and CO2 over ODH have been widely investigated [14–21]. Among these oxidants, the introduction of CO2 into the alkane dehydrogenation process (CO2-EDH) converts the greenhouse gas CO2 into valuable CO, which is favorable for the carbon neutrality [22,23]. As a milder oxidant, CO2 would suppress the deep oxidation of ethylene product to improve ethylene selectivity. In addition, the equilibrium conversion of EDH with CO2 could be enhanced via coupling ethane dehydrogenation and reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction [24]. And it is also reported that CO2 could react with coke via the reverse Boudouard reaction and further improve catalyst stability [25–28]. Recently, many catalysts have been made to investigate CO2-EDH [16,17,29], including supported on different supports noble metal (Pt, Pd, Au, Ru) [30–34], transition metal (Co, Cr, Fe, Ga, In, Zn) catalysts [24,35–41], metal alloy (Fe3Ni, Co3Ni3, PtxCoyInz, PdInx, Pt5Ce) [17,42–44], and nonmetallic oxides (Mo2C, GaN) etc. [45,46]. As shown in Scheme 1 , multiple competing reactions occur between ethane and CO2. In addition to the primary reactions producing ethylene (1, 2), several side reactions are also present, including the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction (3), coke removal (4), ethane dry reforming (6), and ethane cracking and hydrogenolysis (5, 7). Therefore, it is crucial to achieve precise activation of ethane and CO2 by selectively controlling the cleavage of C–C and C–H bonds. From the reaction network of the CO2-EDH system depicted in Scheme 1, the direct dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene (2) is limited by its thermodynamic equilibrium conversion. Enhancing hydrogen consumption through the RWGS reaction (1) can effectively promote ethane conversion. Recently, Bugrova [47] and Zhang [48] et al. investigated the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane with CO2 over CrOx supported catalysts, and found that the ethylene is formed via a direct ethane dehydrogenation accompanied by RWGS, and the introduction of CO2 would promote the removal of H2 via RWGS and suppress the generation of coke via reverse Bouduoard reactions. Yao et al. [49] investigated the CoMoOx moieties for effective coupling of ethane activation and CO2 reduction, and found that the activation of CO2 via RWGS would retain higher O contents in CoMoOx moieties, which would result in more effective activation of CH bond of C2H6 and oxidation of coke precursors. Liu et al. [24,50] investigated Zn-modified SSZ-13 for CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane. They proposed that the introduction of CO2 could effectively lower the energy barrier for the rate-limiting step of the second C–H bond dissociation and facilitate the desorption of ethylene. However, the role of CO2 in this process remains a subject of debate. In this work, the Zn-based SSZ-13 catalyst with alkali metal modifications are prepared and applied for EDH and CO2-EDH. The introduction of alkali metals Na and K and CO2 could obtain the superior ethane dehydrogenation performance with 0.381 mol C2H4 gZn -1 h-1 over CO2-EDH process after 440 min time on stream over Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13. According to the systematic catalysts characterizations and catalytic performance evaluation, the dehydrogenation active sites, the role of alkali metal Na and K as well as CO2 are clarified, which could provide new insight for the future design of high-performance CO2-EDH catalysts. Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation Commercial SSZ-13 with a Si/Al molar ratio of 7 (Dalian Ligong Qiwangda Chemical Technology Co., Ltd) was calcined in flowing air at 550 °C for 6 h with a rate of 1 °C·min−1 before use. Zn x /Na y /K z /SSZ-13 catalysts were prepared via incipient wetness impregnation in the order of loading Na, K and subsequently Zn into the SSZ-13 support, wherein x, y and z represent the weight percentage of Zn, Na and K, respectively. In a typical synthesis, an amount of NaNO3 was dissolved in 0.8 mL deionized water, then it was dropwise added to 1 g SSZ-13 support, then it was dried at 80 °C for 8 h and calcined in flowing air at 650 °C for 3 h with a rate of 2 °C·min−1, and the obtained sample was labeled as Na x /SSZ-13. Afterwards, the further introduction of K and Zn are similar to the procedure of the introduction of Na, finally to synthesize Zn x /Na y /K z /SSZ-13. As comparison, Zn x /SSZ-13 and Zn x /Na y /SSZ-13 are also prepared with the similar methods. In addition, the different metal contents of Zn (1.0–8.0 wt%), Na (0.5–2.0 wt%), K (0.35–2.0 wt%) over support are also prepared. If no special mentioned, the Zn, Na, K loadings over SSZ-13 support are 2.54 wt%, 0.99 wt% and 0.70 wt%, respectively. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku Smartlab diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation and a nickel filter in the 2θ angle range from 5° to 80° at 35 kV and 25 mA. The metal content was measured by ICP-OES on an iCAP-7000 Plus series spectrometer (Thermo-Fisher, USA). Nitrogen physisorption was carried out on an ASAP 2020 (Micrometrics, USA) instrument at 77 K after outgassing the samples for 6 h under vacuum at 300 °C. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded by an FEI Talos F200S G2 at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The UV–Visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–Vis) were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer using a BaSO4 plate as a reference. TG analysis was conducted on an STA 449C Jupiter (Netzsch, Germany) with a rising rate of 10 °C/min in the air for coke measurement. XPS spectra were obtained on an Escalab250xi electron spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) with monochromatic 150 W Al Ka radiation, and the measured binding energies were calibrated against the C1 s peak at 284.8 eV. The temperature-programmed experiments were tested on an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. In a typical NH3-TPD experiment, 100 mg of sample was pretreated in a helium stream (30 mL min−1) at 600 °C for 1 h. The adsorption of NH3 was carried out at 50 °C for 1 h, followed by purging with helium at 100 °C for 2 h to remove physisorbed NH3 from the catalyst surface. The TPD profile was recorded at a heating rate of 5 °C•min-1 from 100 °C to 600 °C. For the C2H4-TPD, 100 mg of each sample was pretreated at 600 °C for 2 h under 30 mL•min-1 Ar and then cooled to 50 °C, then the sample was exposed under C2H4 flow (30 mL•min-1) for 60 min until saturation, followed by purging with He for 60 min to remove physiosorbed C2H4. The temperature was then ramped to 800 °C at 10 °C/min and held for 60 min until complete desorption of C2H4. As for H2-TPR, typically, 100 mg of sample was pretreated in He (30 mL•min-1) at 300 °C for 60 min followed by cooling down to 50 °C, then the sample was reduced in a flow of 10vol.%H2/Ar mixture (50 mL•min-1) from 50 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C•min-1. X-ray adsorption spectra of Zn K edge were obtained on the fluorescence mode on the beamline BL-11B and BL- 14W1, Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (China). The incident X-ray beam was tuned by a Si (111) double-crystal monochromator and then calibrated using a piece of Zn foil. The XAS spectra of the catalyst were collected under fluorescence mode with a solid-state silicon detector. The catalyst sample was pressed into a pellet for measurement under ambient conditions. The XAS data were processed and analyzed using the Demeter software package under the standard protocol [51,52]. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation Catalytic performance evaluation was carried out at the atmospheric pressure in a quartz tubular fixed-bed reactor with a 7 mm inner diameter and 63 cm length. A mixture of 100 mg catalysts and 500 mg quartz sand of 40–60 mesh was loaded in the reactor. The catalyst bed temperature was measured by a thermocouple centered axially inside the reactor. The absence of heat and external mass transfer limitations is confirmed by combining the Mears criterion calculation and changing gas flow rates but constant contact time (constant W/F ratio) experimentally (Table S1 and Figure S1), and the internal mass transfer limitations could be neglected since the estimated Thiele modulus is significantly <1 (Table S2). In a typical reaction condition, firstly, the catalyst was pretreated with 20 mL•min-1 Ar at 650 °C for 1 h, then the reactive gases of C2H6: CO2: Ar with volume ratio of 1:5:34 were introduced into the reactor with a total flow rate of 40 mL min-1. In addition, the introduction of CO2 content was also investigated. The reaction products were analyzed by an online GC-2014 (Shimazu, Japan) equipped with an FID detector to detect hydrocarbons and a TCD detector to detect CO and CO2. The conversion of C2H6 ( X C 2 H 6 ) and CO2 ( X C O 2 ) were calculated according to the following equations: (1) C 2 H 6 conversion : X C 2 H 6 ( % ) = n C 2 H 6 in − n C 2 H 6 out n C 2 H 6 in × 100 (2) C O 2 conversion : X C O 2 ( % ) = n C O 2 in − n C O 2 out n C O 2 in × 100 where n x in and n x out stand for the molar content of C2H6 or CO2 at the inlet and outflow, respectively. In the CO2-EDH reaction, CO2 may react with H2 in an RWGS reaction (CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O), and the conversion of CO2 related to RWGS reaction ( X C O 2 RWGS ) is calculated according to the following equation [53]: (3) X C O 2 RWGS ( % ) = 2 ( n C O 2 in − n C O 2 out ) − n CO out n C O 2 in − n C O 2 out × X C O 2 C2H4 selectivity ( S C 2 H 4 ), C2H4 yield ( Y C 2 H 4 ), normalized C2H4 generation rate, and total carbon balance were calculated according to the following equations: (4) C 2 H 4 selectivity : S C 2 H 4 ( % ) = n C 2 H 4 n C 2 H 6 in − n C 2 H 6 out × 100 (5) C 2 H 4 yield : Y C 2 H 4 ( % ) = X C 2 H 6 × S C 2 H 4 × 100 (6) C 2 H 4 generationrate ( mo l C 2 H 4 · g Zn − 1 · h − 1 ) = Y C 2 H 4 × n C 2 H 6 in t × m Zn (7) Carbon balance ( % ) = 2 n C 2 H 6 out + 2 n C 2 H 4 + n C H 4 + n C O 2 out + n CO 2 n C 2 H 6 in + n C O 2 in × 100 t is the reaction time, and m Z n is the weight of Zn in the catalyst. The deactivation constant kd was calculated according to a first-order deactivation model as an equation as follows [54]: (8) Deactivation parameter kd ( h − 1 ) = [ ln ( 100 − X end X end ) − ln ( 100 − X in X in ) ] t Xend is the C2H6 conversion at the end of the reaction, and Xin is the initial C2H6 conversion. Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and morphological properties of catalysts Fig. 1 A shows the XRD patterns of prepared catalysts, all the catalysts present the typical characteristic peaks of CHA structure, indicating the CHA structure of all the catalysts are well preserved after introducing Zn, K and Na, and no obvious ZnO peaks (PDF#21–1486) are found over the prepared Zn/SSZ-13 catalysts, which could be ascribed to the highly dispersed Zn species or the crystal sizes of Zn species is lower than the detection limitation of XRD. The detailed textural properties of prepared catalysts based on the N2 physisorption at 77 K and ICP characterizations are summarized in Fig. 1B and Table 1 . The Zn, K, Na contents of prepared samples are close to the nominal values. In addition, it is noted that the BET specific surface area and microporous volume decreases correspondingly with the introduction of Zn, Na, and K into SSZ-13, which could be owing to the Zn, Na, and K species occupy the zeolite pore correspondingly. In addition, it is found that the N2 physisorption of an adsorption branch of type IV isotherms are present all the prepared catalysts (Fig. 1B), which could be ascribed to the secondary particles pile pore. Fig. 2 shows the TEM images, the HAADF-STEM images and the corresponding elemental mapping of prepared samples, no obvious aggregates are observed over all the prepared catalysts, and the Zn, K, Na are all distributed homogeneously via the further elemental mapping results, indicating the highly dispersed metal species. The catalyst acidity is further characterized by NH3-TPD, as shown in Fig. 3 . Two obvious desorption peaks at 100–300 °C and 400–600 °C are observed over parent SSZ-13, which could be ascribed to the weak and medium strong acid sites, respectively [55]. Moreover, with the further introduction of Zn over Zn/SSZ-13, the medium acid sites of Zn/SSZ-13 at 400–600 °C disappears and more weak acid sites at 100–300 °C are observed compared with SSZ-13, while the further quantitative analysis in Table 1 shows Zn/SSZ-13 has more acid content than SSZ-13. The decreased medium acid sites of Zn/SSZ-13 could be owing to the compensation of strong Brønsted acid sites of Si-O(H)-Al with Zn species, while the incremental weak acid sites could be owing to the Lewis acids of Zn species. With the subsequent further introduction of Na and K over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, it is noted the corresponding acid sites content is further decreased compared with Zn/SSZ-13, which could be owing to the acidity regulation with alkali metal potassium and sodium ion. 3.2 The catalytic performance evaluation over Zn based catalysts Firstly, the blank experiments of SSZ-13 catalyst over EDH and CO2-EDH are evaluated, as shown in Figure S2, which shows the rather low ethane conversion below 5 %, and the carbon balance and products distribution is shown in Figure S3, it could be found the carbon balance over all the catalysts is higher than 95 % and the acid-catalyzed cracking reactions is low. In addition, the reaction temperature is also optimized, as shown in Figure S4. With the increased temperature from 500 to 650 °C, both the ethane conversion, ethylene yield and CO2 conversion are increased gradually, while the ethylene selectivity is slightly decreased at 650 °C compared with that of 600 °C, which could be ascribed to the presence of cracking side reactions. Correspondingly, 650 °C is adopted as the reaction temperature due to the trade-off between ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity. Fig. 4 and Table 2 show the catalytic performance of prepared Zn-based catalysts. As for EDH, it is noted that initial ethane conversion over Zn/SSZ-13 is 38.5 %, while it decreases to 36.5 % and 31.5 % over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 after the subsequent introduction of Na and K. On the other hand, the ethylene selectivity increases from 67.8 % of Zn/SSZ-13 to 85.6 % (Zn/Na/SSZ-13) and 85.8 % (Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13), respectively. The introduction of alkali metal Na and K would compensate the strong acid sites of SSZ-13, as shown in Fig. 3, the decreased acid sites would suppress the cracking side reactions to improve ethylene selectivity correspondingly. On the other hand, with the simultaneous introduction of ethane and CO2 over CO2-EDH, it is noted that the initial ethane conversion over Zn/SSZ-13, Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 are all improved in comparison with EDH, which demonstrates that the introduction of CO2 would facilitate ethane dehydrogenation. It is observed that with the introduction of alkali metal Na and K, the initial ethylene yield over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 are increased to 46.0 %, and 40.7 %, respectively, which is much higher than that of Zn/SSZ-13 (34.4 %). In addition, the ethylene selectivity is also increased from Zn/SSZ-13 (63.8 %) to Zn/Na/SSZ-13 (67.6 %) and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 (81.4 %), respectively. The corresponding ethylene formation rate normalized by Zn content at time 440 min over decreases in the order of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 (0.381 mol C2H4 gZn -1 h-1) > Zn/Na/SSZ-13 (0.369 mol C2H4 gZn -1 h-1) > Zn/SSZ-13 (0.224 mol C2H4 gZn -1 h-1). Moreover, it is observed that the CO2 conversion and stability over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 are also improved compared with Zn/SSZ-13 (Fig. 4C), and based on the further catalyst stability evaluation results with 440 min time-on-stream, the deactivation rate constant of kd of CO2-EDH over all the catalysts are decreased compared with that of EDH, and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 has the lowest deactivation rate constant kd with 0.04 in comparison with those of other catalysts (Fig. 4F). Moreover, the catalytic performance of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 is also compared with mostly CO2-EDH catalysts according to literature report, as shown in Table S3, demonstrating the superior CO2-EDH catalytic performance of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13. In order to further investigate the time-on-stream stability of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, the corresponding catalytic result is shown Figure S5, the catalytic performance of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 is rather stable and not deactivated obviously (kd=0.02 h-1) with carbon balance higher than 95 % and ethylene selectivity higher than 81 % during 75 h time-on-stream. Moreover, the recycling stability test of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 is shown in Fig. 5 , the ethane conversion is 43.4 % initially and is decreased to 39.9 % after the first 8 h on stream for CO2-EDH reaction, and after the subsequent O2 treatment regeneration, the ethane conversion remains 37.5 % with the slight decrease after four catalytic cycles, which could be owing to the loss of slight Zn specie based on ICP analysis in Fig. 10. In addition, the supported metal content including, Zn (1.0–8.0 wt%), Na (0.5–2.0 wt%) and K (0.35–2.0 wt%) are also optimized correspondingly. The actual metal loadings of the prepared samples are measured by ICP-OES (Table S4), and the corresponding CO2-EDH catalytic results are shown in Figure S6 and Table S5. It is noted that the initial C2H6 and CO2 conversion increase significantly with the increased Zn content when Zn content is lower than 3.0 wt% and then remains stable (Figure S6A-C), and with the subsequent introduction of Na content, the C2H6 conversion is initial increased and then decreased (Figure S6D-F). After the further introduction of K, it is found that the C2H6 conversion is decreased gradually, while the ethylene selectivity and catalyst stability are improved correspondingly (Figure S6G-I). The improved ethylene selectivity after introducing Na and K could be owing to that the alkali metal sites could compensate the acid sites of SSZ-13 to suppress the cracking side reactions. On the other hand, the proper Na (0.5 % and 1.0 %) could improve the ethane conversion, while the further introduction of K would decrease the ethane conversion, which could be owing to that the proper alkali metal sites could promote the CO2 adsorption to improve catalytic performance, while too much alkali metal may cover the Zn sites. To balance the ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity, 3.0 wt% Zn, 1.0 wt% Na and 0.7wt% K are optimized as the proper metal content over the prepared catalysts correspondingly. In order to investigate the effect of CO2, the products distribution of EDH and CO2-EDH are further analyzed, as shown in Fig. 6 . As for EDH without introducing CO2, the C2H4/H2 molar ratio over all the catalysts is lower than 1.0 during 440 min time on stream, and the initial C2H4/H2 molar ratio decreases in the order of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 (0.80) > Zn/Na/SSZ-13 (0.70) > Zn/SSZ-13 (0.58), which indicates the cracking side reactions exist over all three catalysts and the corresponding cracking reaction proportion over Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 is the lowest. After the further introduction of CO2 over CO2-EDH, it is found the C2H4/H2 molar ratio are obviously higher than those of EDH reaction system, and the initial C2H4/H2 molar ratio decreases in the order of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 (2.16) > Zn/Na/SSZ-13 (1.32) > Zn/SSZ-13 (0.98), and the initial C2H4/CO molar ratio presents the similar trend. In addition, it is noted that the corresponding C2H4/H2 at time 440 min are all higher than 1, indicating that the H2 is consumed via RWGS reaction and the cracking side reaction is suppressed obviously. According to the further CO2 conversion analysis in Figure S7, mostly CO2 over these catalysts is consumed via RWGS reaction with the RWGS proportion higher than 90 % and the proportion of ethane dry reforming is negligible. Based on the above catalytic performance evaluation, it is confirmed that the introduction of CO2 over CO2-EDH presents much better catalytic performance compared with EDH, and the introduction of Na and K could further improve the CO2-EDH catalytic activity and catalyst stability. 3.3 The active sites for EDH In order to analyze the improved catalytic performance via introducing alkalis and CO2, systematic characterization methods including H2-TPR, UV–Vis, XAS, and XPS, TPD, ICP and TG analysis are conducted. Fig. 7 A shows the H2-TPR of prepared catalysts, a major reduction peak at about 450 °C is observed over Zn/SSZ-13, which could be ascribed to the reduction of ZnOx species. In addition, with the introduction of Na and K over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, the low-temperature ZnOx reduction peak intensity at about 450 °C is decreased obviously and a higher reduction peak is observed at about 733 °C, indicating the reduction of ZnOx species is suppressed obviously owing to a stronger metal-support interaction. And from the UV–Vis characterization results in Fig. 7B, the absorption band at 220 nm is observed over all three samples, which is assigned to the isolated Zn2+ sites caused by O2- to Zn2+ charge transfer transitions [56], indicating the highly dispersed Zn2+ sites over the prepared catalysts. In order to further reveal the actual Zn species, the UV–Vis spectra of catalysts after 1 h EDH and CO2-EDH are shown in Fig. 7C and D. As for catalysts after 1 h EDH, four absorption bands at 240, 275, 322 and 337 nm appears over all the prepared catalysts, which are assigned to the aggregated ZnO clusters and ZnO NPs, respectively [56–58]. Moreover, two absorption bands at about 397 and 452 nm assigned to the low-condensed aromatics species [59] is observed over the prepared catalysts, and the corresponding bands intensity is decreased over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 compared with parent Zn/SSZ-13, demonstrating that the introduction of Na and K would suppress the corresponding side reactions. After the further introduction of CO2 over CO2-EDH, besides the absorption bands of ZnO clusters and ZnO NPs are observed over all the prepared catalysts, the absorption band at 220 nm assigned to isolated Zn2+ sites is still maintained over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, and the corresponding bands intensity at 397 and 452 nm assigned to the low-condensed aromatics species over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 is also lower than that of Zn/SSZ-13. Above H2-TPR and UV–Vis characterization results demonstrate that the introduction of alkalis Na and K and CO2 would facilitate to suppress the reduction of ZnOx species and maintain the Zn active species. The chemical state at the surface of the catalyst is further studied by Zn 2p XPS, as shown in Figure S8, the binding energies of 1047.2 eV and 1024.2 eV are observed over all the catalysts, which are assigned to the Zn 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 photoelectrons of Zn sites, respectively, corresponding to Zn2+ oxidation state [60]. Owing to the difficulty of distinguishing the chemical environments of Zn species by Zn 2p spectra, Zn LMM Auger transition is further performed to characterize the existing electronic state of Zn species, as shown in Figure S8C. Besides a central band at 498.6–500.7 eV attributed to ZnO species is observed all the prepared catalysts. A central band located at 496.7 eV is observed over Zn/SSZ-13, which could be ascribed to metallic Zn0 species [61,62], while no obvious metallic Zn0 species is observed over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, indicating that the introduction of Na and K would inhibit the reduction of ZnOx species, in accordance with above H2-TPR results. The chemical state and coordination environment of Zn in the Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 catalysts are further studied by the X-ray absorption spectrum (XAS) including X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS), as shown in Fig. 8 . The spectra of zinc foil and ZnO are also presented as the references. In the XANES of Zn K-edge, the Zn K-edge patterns of Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 are close to the ZnO but far from the Zn reference, which indicates the Zn species exists in the form of ZnO, in accordance with previous UV–Vis results. The coordination environment of Zn of the Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 catalysts are further studied by Fourier transformed EXAFS of Zn K-edge, both Fourier transformed spectra are present without phase correction in Fig. 8B. The Fourier transform moduli are limited to the first shell of neighbors (up to R = 6.0 Å). A first shell Zn-O coordination with the distance of 1.56 Å is obtained over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, which is similar with ZnO. In addition, from the catalytic results in Fig. 4, it is noted that the C2H4 selectivity over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 is also improved accordingly with the sequential addition of alkali metals Na and K. The low C2H4 selectivity over Zn/SSZ-13 may come from the cracking side reactions induced by the Bronsted acid sites. Correspondingly, the C2H4-TPD profiles of the prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . All samples present a low-temperature C2H4 desorption peak at about 155 °C, while two higher C2H4 desorption temperature peaks are observed at 347 °C and 528 °C over Zn/SSZ-13. The higher C2H4 desorption temperatures would accelerate the further cracking of C2H4 to generate coke, resulting in lower C2H4 selectivity and carbon balance. With the subsequent introduction of alkali metals Na and K, the two C2H4 desorption temperatures peaks disappear obviously, indicating that the cracking side reactions are suppressed correspondingly, resulting in the higher C2H4 selectivity. 3.4 Characterization of spent catalyst From the previous catalytic results in Fig. 4, it is noted that the corresponding ethane conversion decreases gradually, and the further UV–Vis characterization results (Fig. 7B-D) reveals that the Zn peak intensity is deceased. In order to analyze the Zn loss over EDH and CO2-EDH, the actual loadings of all the Zn-based samples were analyzed by ICP-OES, as shown in Fig. 10 . The actual Zn contents of the fresh catalysts are consistent with the desired values. It is noted that the Zn contents of the prepared samples after 8 h EDH is much lower with 50 % Zn loss compared with those of the fresh catalysts, which could be due to the reduction ZnOx species to metallic Zn species and the subsequent volatilization of metallic zinc during the reductive H2 atmosphere [63,64]. As comparison, the loss of Zn species is significantly suppressed after the further introduction of CO2 over CO2-EDH for 8 h, only about 2.8 % and 1.9 % Zn loss are observed over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, respectively. The suppression of Zn loss could be attributed to the existence of oxidative protective CO2 [44]. Moreover, it is also found that the Zn content are relatively stable even after 20 h CO2-EDH, demonstrating that the introduction of CO2 could well inhibit the loss of Zn species and further improve the activity and stability of the catalyst. In addition, TG and TEM are also adopted to characterize the spent catalysts, as shown in Fig. 11 and Figure S9. From the TG results in Fig. 11, as for EDH, it is noted that the TG loss content between 100 and 800 °C over Zn/SSZ-13 is 11.02 %, while it decreases to 6.01 % and 5.64 % over Zn/Na/SSZ-13 and Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, which indicates that the introduction of Na and K would suppress the cracking side reactions via compensating the acid sites. Moreover, with the simultaneous introduction of ethane and CO2 over CO2-EDH, it could be found that the coke content is obviously lower than those of EDH process and decreases in the order of Zn/SSZ-13 (9.04 %) > Zn/Na/SSZ-13 (5.21 %) > Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 (3.03 %), demonstrating that CO2 could react with coke via the reverse Boudouard reaction and further improve catalyst stability. In the meantime, the introduction of Na and K could also effectively inhibit the formation of coke, hence the ethylene selectivity and carbon balance are improved correspondingly. Figure S9 shows the TEM images of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13-used catalyst after 480 min on stream. No obvious particles are observed over Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 (CO2-EDH), demonstrating that Zn species is still maintained highly dispersed (Figure S9B). However, obvious particles are observed over Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 (EDH) (Figure S9A). Hence, it is reasonable to conclude that the presence of CO2 could inhibit the aggregation of ZnO NPs. 3.4 The influence of CO2 ratio Based on previous investigation, it is confirmed that the introduction of CO2 would improve corresponding catalytic performance. To further investigate the effect of CO2, the catalytic performance of Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 with the different CO2 ratios over 8 h CO2-EDH is investigated, as shown in Fig. 12 . With the gradually increased CO2 concentration of C2H6: CO2 ratio from 1:0 to 1:7, it is noted that the initial carbon balance is increased from 93.9 % to 99.2 % correspondingly (Figure S3), meanwhile, the initial C2H6 conversion is increased from 40.4 % to 51.9 %, and the C2H4 yield shows the similar trend. Moreover, the deactivation rate constant of kd is decreased from 0.18 to 0.04 with the increased CO2 concentration, while the ethylene selectivity is slightly decreased when C2H6: CO2 ratio is increased to 1:3, which could be owing to the high ethane conversion. Above catalytic results indicate that the introduction of CO2 would improve the catalytic performance and catalyst stability, and the highest C2H4 yield is achieved with 41.6 % at time 480 min when C2H6: CO2 ratio is 1:7. In order to further investigate the effect of CO2, the products distribution of CO2-EDH over Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 with different CO2 contents are further analyzed, as shown in Fig. 13 . With the increased CO2 content, the detected H2 content is decreased gradually. It is found that the C2H4/H2 molar ratio is lower than 1.0 during 440 min time on stream without introducing CO2, which could be owing to the cracking side reactions. With the further increased CO2 content, the C2H4/H2 molar ratio is increased gradually and is the highest with 2.6 when C2H6/CO2 molar ratio is 1:7, demonstrating that the introduction of more CO2 would react with H2 via RWGS reaction. In the meantime, the products distribution of C2H4 is also investigated, as shown in Fig. 13B, with the increased CO2 content, the C2H6/CO molar ratio is decreased gradually, indicating more CO is generated via RWGS reaction. In addition, according to the further CO2 conversion analysis in Figure S10, with the increased CO2 content from the C2H6/CO2 molar ratio 2:1 to 1:5, the proportion of CO2 conversion via RWGS is increased gradually, and then slightly decreases with C2H6/CO2 molar ratio of 1:7 (Figure S10B). Based on the calculated specific consumed CO2 content in Figure S10C, it is found that the consumed CO2 content is increased with the increased the CO2 concentration. Combined with the results of the proportion of CO2 conversion via RWGS, it is reasonable to conclude that the higher concentration of CO2 would facilitate more CO2 to participate in RWGS, while too much CO2 content would also lead to a slight increase in ethane dry reforming with C2H6/CO2 molar ratio of 1:7. In the meantime, the Zn content and Zn loss over Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 for 8 h CO2-EDH is further analyzed by ICP-OES, as shown in Fig. 14 . It is worth noting that the Zn content is closer to the initial value with the increased CO2 concentration (Fig. 14A), and 2.51 wt% Zn is remained with C2H6: CO2 = 1:7 compared with merely 1.1 wt% Zn without CO2 introduction, and the further Zn loss analysis shows that minimum 1.2 % Zn is lost with C2H6: CO2 = 1:7 compared with that of 55.5 % Zn loss when C2H6: CO2 = 1:0 (Fig. 14B), indicating that the introduction of CO2 could inhabit the loss of Zn species. In addition, the coke content after the reaction with different CO2 content is further analyzed by TG, as shown in Figure S11. With the increased CO2 content of C2H6/CO2 ratio from 1:0 to 1:7, it is noted that the coke content is decreased from 5.64 % to 2.94 %, correspondingly, suggesting that the introduction of CO2 has a positive effect on the inhibition of coke compared with the EDH process (C2H6: CO2 = 1:0). In summary, according to above characterizations results, it is confirmed that the presence of CO2 over CO2-EDH process could not only suppress the Zn loss to maintain active Zn species, but also could significantly inhibits coke generation, to finally realize the promotion of catalytic activity and catalytic stability. 4 Conclusion In summary, the Zn-based SSZ-13 catalysts with Na and K modifications are investigated over EDH and CO2-EDH process. Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 presents the superior ethane dehydrogenation performance with 0.381 mol C2H4 gZn -1 h-1 over CO2-EDH process after 440 min time on stream. According to the systematic characterizations, it is confirmed that isolated Zn2+ species is the active sites, the introduction of alkali metal would reduce the acid sites and further suppress the cracking side reactions, and the further introduction of CO2 would reduce the loss of Zn content as a protective atmosphere and suppress the coke deposition, and to finally realize the promotion of ethane dehydrogenation activity via RWGS reaction. It is revealed that with the increased CO2 concentration, the loss of Zn is suppresed obviously and the proportion of RWGS is increased correspondingly, which is beneficial to improve CO2-EDH catalytic performance. This work elucidates the isolated Zn2+ species is the active phase of dehydrogenation activity and the role of CO2 over CO2-EDH process, which provides new insight for the future design of high-performance CO2-EDH catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Alkali metal promoted Zn/SSZ-13 catalysts were investigated for ethane dehydrogenation (EDH) and CO2-assisted oxidative ethane dehydrogenation (CO2-EDH). The Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13 demonstrated enhanced ethane dehydrogenation performance, achieving 0.381 mol C2H4 gZn -1 h-1 with a low deactivation rate constant of (kd) of 0.04 h-1 in the CO2-EDH process after 440 min time on stream, compared to the unmodified Zn/SSZ-13 catalyst. Comprehensive characterizations revealed that the isolated Zn2+ species serve as the active sites for dehydrogenation, while the addition of alkali metals compensate the acid sites of SSZ-13, effectively suppressing the side reactions such as cracking. Moreover, the introduction of CO2 mitigates Zn loss and enhances catalyst activity and stability by coupling with the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS), which also suppress the coke deposition. Investigation of vary CO2 content indicated that higher CO2 concentrations significantly suppress Zn loss and increase the proportion of the RWGS reaction, thereby improving CO2-EDH catalytic performance. This work elucidates the active phase of ethane dehydrogenation and highlights the role of alkali metals and CO2 in the CO2-EDH process over Zn/Na/K/SSZ-13, providing valuable insights for designing high-performance CO2-EDH catalysts.
